title: 114_hr3956
content: The Act may be cited as the "VA Health Center Management Stability and Improvement Act". Congress finds that the Department of Veterans Affairs is facing challenges with the management of medical centers, including the frequent turnover of directors due to the inability to recruit permanent candidates. This turnover hinders long-term planning and system management functions. The Department of Veterans Affairs is struggling with managing medical centers due to frequent turnover of directors, hindering long-term planning and service delivery. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs should develop a plan to recruit permanent directors at centers lacking one. The Department of Veterans Affairs is facing challenges in managing medical centers due to director turnover. A plan is needed to hire permanent directors at centers without one. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must develop a plan within 120 days to hire qualified directors for VA medical centers lacking permanent directors. The plan should set deadlines for hiring, address hiring obstacles, and explore promoting and training internal candidates for senior positions. The Secretary must submit this plan to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs of the House of Representatives and the Senate within the same timeframe. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit semiannual reports to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs of the House of Representatives and the Senate listing VA medical centers without permanent directors. SEC. 4. COMPLIANCE WITH SCHEDULING REQUIREMENTS. Annual Certification: The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must ensure that each medical facility certifies compliance with scheduling laws and regulations annually. Waivers are prohibited, and noncompliance requires a report with explanations and corrective actions. The director of a medical facility must ensure compliance with laws and regulations. If certification is not made, certain officials are prohibited from receiving bonuses. Covered officials include the director, chief of staff, and associate director. The Secretary must submit an annual report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs listing certified and non-certified medical facilities, along with reports submitted under subsection (b). The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must ensure that the Department's directives and policies are uniformly applied to all offices and facilities. If there is a deviation, the Secretary must notify the Committees on Veterans' Affairs with an explanation.
